citations.narrative:
Multiple primary enclosures do not have a sufficient public barrier present, including the primary enclosure for one
dromedary camel and the primary enclosure for 5 goats. During the inspection, the camel was seen to lean over both the
primary enclosure fence and the public barrier in order to access the public space. The enclosure for the goats has no
barrier present.
Inadequate public barriers increase the risk of harm to both the animals and to the public. During public exhibition, any
animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or
barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals and the public.
To be corrected by January 8, 2024.

While the animal exhibits are open, the facility hands out bags of food for the public to feed the animals. Due to the layout
of the facility, the attendant at the food station cannot see all animal exhibits where the public hands out food. This
includes the camel exhibit where the camel is able to reach over the public barrier. The inspector witnessed two members
of the public feeding the camel without an attendant present.
Without an attendant, there is no way to ensure animal or public safety, especially during feeding. A responsible,
knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public
contact.
To be corrected by December 22, 2023.

In the enclosure for one goat, the chain link fence has started to curl up in multiple places and is no longer flush with the
ground. This has created gaps in the fence as well as sharp points from the bent fencing.
In the enclosures for the two zebras and the two zedonks, there are numerous strings of baling twine leftover from hay
that was fed to the animals.
Fences in disrepair can cause injury or lead to escape. Inappropriate materials in the enclosure can lead to ingestion or
entanglement. All housing facilities must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the
animals involved. All housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Multiple primary enclosures do not have a sufficient public barrier present, including the primary enclosure for one 
dromedary camel and the primary enclosure for 5 goats. During the inspection, the camel was seen to lean over both the 
primary enclosure fence and the public barrier in order to access the public space. The enclosure for the goats has no 
barrier present.  
 
Inadequate public barriers increase the risk of harm to both the animals and to the public. During public exhibition, any 
animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or 
barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals and the public.  
 
To be corrected by January 8, 2024. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
While the animal exhibits are open, the facility hands out bags of food for the public to feed the animals. Due to the layout 
of the facility, the attendant at the food station cannot see all animal exhibits where the public hands out food. This 
includes the camel exhibit where the camel is able to reach over the public barrier. The inspector witnessed two members 
of the public feeding the camel without an attendant present.  
 
Without an attendant, there is no way to ensure animal or public safety, especially during feeding. A responsible, 
knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods of public 
contact.  
 
To be corrected by December 22, 2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general.

In the enclosure for one goat, the chain link fence has started to curl up in multiple places and is no longer flush with the 
ground. This has created gaps in the fence as well as sharp points from the bent fencing. 
In the enclosures for the two zebras and the two zedonks, there are numerous strings of baling twine leftover from hay 
that was fed to the animals.  
 
Fences in disrepair can cause injury or lead to escape. Inappropriate materials in the enclosure can lead to ingestion or 
entanglement. All housing facilities must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the 
animals involved. All housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
